body.p:
REMOVED TO CORNER OF SEVENTH AND MAIN.
D. B. LEIGHT & CO.
IMPORTERS AND DEALERS IN FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC DRY GOODS,
604 Main Street, between Sixth and Seventh, Louisville, Ky.

D. B. LEIGHT,
ROB'T F. COOKE,
LATEN B. PORCH.
Hon E L. Van Winkle
Secretary of State
Sir -- About the first part of July a young man employed in one of the largest retail dry goods stores of this city was arrested on the charge of having taken from the store two lb of sewing silk -- He was about From the city at the time the silk was missed & was brought from Mt Washington in the state to the city & had a hearing before the city court Judge He was taken completely by surprise & had no time to prepare for his trial or confer with an attorney -- He was committed to await his trial at the September term of our Circuit Court -- The young man (his name was Earnest Cramer) had circulatd with the young men of the city
and made a very respectable appearance in our city -- He had host of friends to attend him in his prosperity but when he feel he was deserted by all -- I had no acquaintance with the Young man & never saw him to know him until I visited him at his prison He had no one to bail him for trial & perfectly crest fallen he solicited my sympathies -- He had attended regularly I understood from one of our members the Presbyterian church of Mr McKee and his many protestations of innocence together with the hope of reclaiming him from his errors if he had committed any upon me to such an extent that I was prevailed to assist him to this extent -- He had one hundred Dolls in gold which was equivalent to $140 & his bail
amounted to $300 I advanced the remaining $150 for him, he promising me faithfully to present himself for trial on the 1st monday in September -- In the mean time he was to remain with a friend he had at Mt Washington -- He was a german by birth & to all appearances an innocent unoffending simple person & not a person who would have been thought a criminal -- Shortly before Court day I received a letter From him postmarked New York stating that he would sail in a few days for the Barbadoes, that he could not stand his trial, feeling that he was guilty, acknoweldging the crime & promising to reform his life & be henceforth a better man -- I enclosed this letter from him to Gov Bramlette in a previous letter on the subject & is doubtless now among the papers in
his office -- I have not heard from since & hope to be able to have that portion I advanced for his bail refunded -- The bail was forfeited at the September term of the Jefferson Circuit Court -- Hoping the brief statement may meet Your attention & if possible relieve me from a loss I can illy stand

Respy Yr Obd Srvt
J. M Reamer

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Remit -- $160 of the forfeiture --
J M Reamer
Remitted 15 Dec/65
